p: Transmission of arboviruses via blood transfusion has been reported for dengue viruses (DENVs) and West Nile virus (WNV) [ 1], and suspected for other arboviruses. In Australia, outbreaks of DENVs and Ross River virus (RRV) threaten blood transfusion safety [ 2]. Zika virus (ZIKV), closely related to DENVs and WNV, is an emerging arbovirus with potential for transfusion-transmission [ 3– 8]. ZIKV may be detected in serum or plasma for 1–2 weeks after infection and persists for longer periods of time in whole blood, red blood cells, semen, and urine [ 9– 11]. Therefore, ZIKV presents yet another challenge to blood transfusion providers and to public health generally, as transfusion recipients could develop ZIKV-related disease following transfusion.
